 Correct Solution: Color Cakeland as follows, i.e. each column alternatively abcd and dcba:
a d a d...
b c b c...
c b c b...
d a d a...
Then there are 12 squares of each color. Again we suppose that the lower left corner is black. Then a and c are normal white squares while b and d are normal black squares. Additionally, we notice that each a-square must be preceded and followed by a b-square. This will require more b-squares than a-squares, but there are 12 squares of each color.
Therefore, the knight couldn't achieve his goal.
Hint:
If you can't figure it out, try coloring Cakeland in another way:
a d a d...
b c b c...
c b c b...
d a d a...
Then there are 12 squares of each color.
Human Solution:
Color Cakeland as follows, i.e. each column alternatively abcd and dcba:
a d a d...
b c b c...
c b c b...
d a d a...
Then there are 12 squares of each color. Again we suppose that the lower left corner is black. Then a and c are normal white squares while b and d are normal black squares. Additionally, we notice that each a-square must be preceded and followed by a b-square. This will require more b-squares than a-squares, but there are 12 squares of each color.
Therefore, the knight couldn't achieve his goal.
Response:
After comparing the two write–ups, there is actually no mathematical mistake in the argument I gave.  
Schwenk’s theorem really does say that a rectangular m × n board (with m ≤ n) fails to admit a closed knight’s tour whenever m = 1, 2, 4; when m = 3 and n = 4, 6, 8; or when m and n are both odd.  
Because a 12 × 4 board has the shorter side m = 4, it falls under the “m = 4” obstruction, so a closed knight’s tour is impossible – exactly the conclusion reached by the official solution.

The difference between the two solutions is only the mode of proof:

•  I appealed to the global classification supplied by Schwenk.  
•  The official solution gives an ad-hoc 4-colouring/parity argument that shows directly why a 12 × 4 board cannot be toured and returned.

Thus our answers coincide; my solution is simply less constructive (it does not explain “where” the imbalance arises) but it is still correct.  No missed cases or logical errors have been found.

Question:
Question: You are a scenery creator for plays and you have just been asked to create the Balcony for Romeo and Juliet.
The stage is 7m from the floor to the spotlights.
The balcony has to be a full circle (the other half will act as a platform for the actors waiting on the other side of the wall).
The balcony floor is 30cm thick.
The balcony needs a 1m(height) x 10cm(thickness) solid fence surrounding the perimeter of the half that will be seen by the audience.
The floor of the balcony must be exactly 4m from the ground.
The balcony is like so in order for the spot light (that shines at a 45 degree angle to the roof) will cover the entire balcony precisely when it is positioned above the middle of the balcony.
Pine is cheap at exactly $1 per 5000cm^3, tax included.
Exactly how much money will you spend to build the balcony?
Conversions:
100cm = 1m
2.54cm = 1inch
 Your Solution: [SEE HINT]
Therefore, the stage will be solved by the formula for a cylinder, [pi(r)^2]h where r = 300cm and h = 30cm (rule 3).
The balcony now needs a 100 cm x 10 cm solid fence. This now defies the simple rules of perimeter, you must incorporate the loss of radius per added centimeter towards the middle. In other words, you solve for the perimeter 10 times with the thickness valued as 1, incorporating the new radius each time. Remember, since it is only on one half, each answer must be halved.
2pi(r) finds the perimeter. Then multiplied by the height will be formulated 2pi(r)h where r = 300cm and h = 100cm. Since we only need half of that, it will be [2pi(r)h]/2 = pi(r)h.
Then we need to find the 9 other rings incorporating the loss of radius.
pi(r-1)h + pi(r-2)h + pi(r-3)h + pi(r-4)h + pi(r-5)h + pi(r-6)h + pi(r-7)h + pi(r-8)h + pi(r-9)h
This added to pi(r)h will yield the volume of the fence surrounding half of the stage.
Thus, the final equation will be:
let a represent the height of the room, then b represent the height of the balcony off the floor, then f represent the thickness of the balcony floor, then r represent a-b or the radius of the balcony floor, then h represent the height of the fence.
V = {[pi(a-b)^2]f + [pi(r)h + pi(r-1)h + pi(r-2)h + pi(r-3)h + pi(r-4)h + pi(r-5)h + pi(r-6)h + pi(r-7)h + pi(r-8)h + pi(r-9)h]}
= {[pi(90000)30] + [pi(300)100 + pi(299)100 + pi(298)100 ... ... pi(291)100]}
= {(2 700 000pi) + [30 000pi + 29 900pi + 29 800pi + 29 700pi ... ... 29 100pi]}
~= 8482300.16469244 + 928340.629135783
~= 9410640.79382822 cm^3
If pine is cheap at exactly $1 per 5000cm^3, tax included,
the price is then:
P ~= (9410640.79382822 / 5000) * 1.00
~= $1882.13
 Correct Solution: Step 1 – Find the balcony’s radius  
The spot‑light is 7 m above the floor, the balcony floor is 4 m above the floor, so the vertical drop from the light to the balcony surface is

        h = 7 m – 4 m = 3 m.

Because the beam makes a 45° angle, the horizontal reach equals the vertical drop; therefore the balcony’s radius is

        r = h = 3 m = 300 cm.

Step 2 – Volume of the circular floor  
Thickness of the floor = 30 cm.  
Volume

        V_floor = π r² t
                = π (300 cm)² (30 cm)
                = π · 90 000 · 30
                = 2 700 000 π cm³.

Step 3 – Volume of the fence  
Only the audience‑side half‑circumference gets a fence.

        Half‑circumference = π r = π·300 cm = 300π cm.
        Height            = 1 m = 100 cm.
        Thickness         = 10 cm.

        V_fence = (length)(height)(thickness)
                = (300π)(100)(10)
                = 300 000 π cm³.

Step 4 – Total volume of pine

        V_total = V_floor + V_fence
                = 2 700 000 π + 300 000 π
                = 3 000 000 π cm³.

Step 5 – Cost  
Pine costs $1 per 5 000 cm³, so

        Cost = V_total / 5 000
             = (3 000 000 π) / 5 000
             = 600 π dollars
             ≈ 600 · 3.14159
             ≈ $1 884.96.

Final answer: $1,884.96
Hint: If the floor of the balcony is 4 meters from the ground, and the room is 7 meters, then the floor is 3 meters from the spotlight. If the spot light shines at a 45 degree angle and the spot light will cover the entire balcony precisely when it is positioned above the middle of the balcony, then the radius of the balcony floor will be 3 meters (if the hypotenuse of a triangle is at a 45 degree angle to the y axis (and the side x is 90 degrees to the side y), the side x will always equal the side y and the remaining side will be the hypotenuse of those [the rules of an isosceles triangle]).
Human Solution:
[SEE HINT]
Therefore, the stage will be solved by the formula for a cylinder, [pi(r)^2]h where r = 300cm and h = 30cm (rule 3).
The balcony now needs a 100 cm x 10 cm solid fence. This now defies the simple rules of perimeter, you must incorporate the loss of radius per added centimeter towards the middle. In other words, you solve for the perimeter 10 times with the thickness valued as 1, incorporating the new radius each time. Remember, since it is only on one half, each answer must be halved.
2pi(r) finds the perimeter. Then multiplied by the height will be formulated 2pi(r)h where r = 300cm and h = 100cm. Since we only need half of that, it will be [2pi(r)h]/2 = pi(r)h.
Then we need to find the 9 other rings incorporating the loss of radius.
pi(r-1)h + pi(r-2)h + pi(r-3)h + pi(r-4)h + pi(r-5)h + pi(r-6)h + pi(r-7)h + pi(r-8)h + pi(r-9)h
This added to pi(r)h will yield the volume of the fence surrounding half of the stage.
Thus, the final equation will be:
let a represent the height of the room, then b represent the height of the balcony off the floor, then f represent the thickness of the balcony floor, then r represent a-b or the radius of the balcony floor, then h represent the height of the fence.
V = {[pi(a-b)^2]f + [pi(r)h + pi(r-1)h + pi(r-2)h + pi(r-3)h + pi(r-4)h + pi(r-5)h + pi(r-6)h + pi(r-7)h + pi(r-8)h + pi(r-9)h]}
= {[pi(90000)30] + [pi(300)100 + pi(299)100 + pi(298)100 ... ... pi(291)100]}
= {(2 700 000pi) + [30 000pi + 29 900pi + 29 800pi + 29 700pi ... ... 29 100pi]}
~= 8482300.16469244 + 928340.629135783
~= 9410640.79382822 cm^3
If pine is cheap at exactly $1 per 5000cm^3, tax included,
the price is then:
P ~= (9410640.79382822 / 5000) * 1.00
~= $1882.13
Response:
Main source of error – the fence  

The balcony floor was handled correctly: you used a 3 m (300 cm) radius and a 30 cm thickness and obtained  
π·300²·30 = 2 700 000 π cm³ – exactly the same value as the official solution.

Almost the entire discrepancy comes from the way you computed the volume of the 1 m × 10 cm fence that is wrapped round the audience-side half of the circle.

1.  Wrong geometric model  
   •  The fence is a “half-annular” shell: the region between two concentric half-circles of radii 300 cm (outer) and 290 cm (inner) that is 100 cm high.  
   •  Its volume is therefore  
          ½·π(300² − 290²)·100  
          = ½·π·5 900·100  
          = 295 000 π cm³.  
     – or, equivalently, (half-circumference at the outer radius) × height × thickness  
          (300π) · 100 · 10 = 300 000 π cm³  
       (the official solution rounded up by taking the outer radius for the whole strip).

2.  Your ring-by-ring summation leaves out part of the material and double-counts other parts.  
   •  You treated the 10 cm thickness as ten separate 1-cm “rings” of fence and added  
        π·100(300 + 299 + … + 291) = 295  500 π cm³.  
   •  Problems with this approach:  
       – The inner centimetre (between radii 291 cm and 290 cm) is omitted.  
       – Each 1-cm ring is represented by the larger of its two bounding radii, so the remaining rings are all slightly oversized.  
       – The net effect is an underestimate of about 4 500 π cm³ compared with the correct 300 000 π cm³ in the official answer.

3.  Numerical and cost consequence  
   •  Correct total volume:  
        V_total = 2 700 000 π + 300 000 π = 3 000 000 π ≈ 9 424 778 cm³.  
   •  Cost at $1 per 5 000 cm³:  
        3 000 000 π / 5 000 = 600 π ≈ $1 884.96.  
   •  Your result ($1 882.13) is low by ≈ $2.83, reflecting the fence-volume shortfall.

Minor points

•  The fence calculation can be done in one step; the repeated-radius method is cumbersome and error-prone.  
•  Units: saying “thickness valued as 1” hides the fact that a length dimension is being omitted; always keep the cm in the algebra to avoid dimensional slips.  
•  You do not actually need to reduce the radius successively; using the half-circumference at either the outer radius (as the official solution did) or, more exactly, integrating across the 10 cm thickness is quicker and safer.

In short, everything except the fence was correct; the fence volume was undervalued because of an imprecise “layer-by-layer” method and the omission of the innermost centimetre of material.

Question:
Question: You are a scenery creator for plays and you have just been asked to create the Balcony for Romeo and Juliet.
The stage is 7m from the floor to the spotlights.
The balcony has to be a full circle (the other half will act as a platform for the actors waiting on the other side of the wall).
The balcony floor is 30cm thick.
The balcony needs a 1m(height) x 10cm(thickness) solid fence surrounding the perimeter of the half that will be seen by the audience.
The floor of the balcony must be exactly 4m from the ground.
The balcony is like so in order for the spot light (that shines at a 45 degree angle to the roof) will cover the entire balcony precisely when it is positioned above the middle of the balcony.
Pine is cheap at exactly $1 per 5000cm^3, tax included.
Exactly how much money will you spend to build the balcony?
Conversions:
100cm = 1m
2.54cm = 1inch
 Your Solution: Step 1 – Find the balcony’s radius  
The spot‑light is 7 m above the floor, the balcony floor is 4 m above the floor, so the vertical drop from the light to the balcony surface is

        h = 7 m – 4 m = 3 m.

Because the beam makes a 45° angle, the horizontal reach equals the vertical drop; therefore the balcony’s radius is

        r = h = 3 m = 300 cm.

Step 2 – Volume of the circular floor  
Thickness of the floor = 30 cm.  
Volume

        V_floor = π r² t
                = π (300 cm)² (30 cm)
                = π · 90 000 · 30
                = 2 700 000 π cm³.

Step 3 – Volume of the fence  
Only the audience‑side half‑circumference gets a fence.

        Half‑circumference = π r = π·300 cm = 300π cm.
        Height            = 1 m = 100 cm.
        Thickness         = 10 cm.

        V_fence = (length)(height)(thickness)
                = (300π)(100)(10)
                = 300 000 π cm³.

Step 4 – Total volume of pine

        V_total = V_floor + V_fence
                = 2 700 000 π + 300 000 π
                = 3 000 000 π cm³.

Step 5 – Cost  
Pine costs $1 per 5 000 cm³, so

        Cost = V_total / 5 000
             = (3 000 000 π) / 5 000
             = 600 π dollars
             ≈ 600 · 3.14159
             ≈ $1 884.96.

Final answer: $1,884.96
 Correct Solution: [SEE HINT]

In other words, you solve for the perimeter 10 times with the thickness valued as 1, incorporating the new radius each time. Remember, since it is only on one half, each answer must be halved.
2pi(r) finds the perimeter. Then multiplied by the height will be formulated 2pi(r)h where r = 300cm and h = 100cm. Since we only need half of that, it will be [2pi(r)h]/2 = pi(r)h.
Then we need to find the 9 other rings incorporating the loss of radius.
pi(r-1)h + pi(r-2)h + pi(r-3)h + pi(r-4)h + pi(r-5)h + pi(r-6)h + pi(r-7)h + pi(r-8)h + pi(r-9)h
This added to pi(r)h will yield the volume of the fence surrounding half of the stage.
Thus, the final equation will be:
let a represent the height of the room, then b represent the height of the balcony off the floor, then f represent the thickness of the balcony floor, then r represent a-b or the radius of the balcony floor, then h represent the height of the fence.
V = {[pi(a-b)^2]f + [pi(r)h + pi(r-1)h + pi(r-2)h + pi(r-3)h + pi(r-4)h + pi(r-5)h + pi(r-6)h + pi(r-7)h + pi(r-8)h + pi(r-9)h]}
= {[pi(90000)30] + [pi(300)100 + pi(299)100 + pi(298)100 ... ... pi(291)100]}
= {(2 700 000pi) + [30 000pi + 29 900pi + 29 800pi + 29 700pi ... ... 29 100pi]}
~= 8482300.16469244 + 928340.629135783
~= 9410640.79382822 cm^3

the price is then:

Response:
Main discrepancy between your work and the intended one lies in the way you computed the volume of the 1 m × 10 cm fence.

WHAT YOU DID  
• You took only the outside half-circumference (300 π cm) and multiplied it by the thickness (10 cm) and the height (100 cm):

 Vfence = (300 π)(10)(100) = 300 000 π cm³.

This treats the fence as if every “strip” of wood had the same length 300 π cm – i.e. you slid a 10 cm-wide rectangular slab of wood round the arc.  
That ignores the fact that, as soon as you move one centimetre toward the centre, the length of the semicircular strip shortens.

WHAT HAS TO BE DONE  
The fence is the solid lying between two concentric semicircles of radii r = 300 cm and r – 10 cm = 290 cm and of height 100 cm.  
Volume of a semicircular ring of thickness 10 cm:

 Vfence = height · ( areaouter semicircle − areainner semicircle )
     = 100 · ( ½πr² − ½π(r – 10)² )
     = 100 · ½π (r² − (r – 10)²)
     = 100 · ½π (20r − 100)
     = 100 · ½π (20·300 − 100)
     = 100 · ½π · 5900
     = 295 000 π cm³.

The correct solution does the same thing by summing ten 1-cm-thick semicircular “rings”:

 πh[(r) + (r − 1) + … + (r − 9)] = π·100·(10r − 45) = 295 500 π cm³,

only 500 π larger than the exact formula because of the 1-cm step approximation.  
Either way, the sound answer is about 295 000 π cm³, not 300 000 π cm³.

CONSEQUENCES  
Total volume you should have used:

 Vtotal = 2 700 000 π + 295 000 π = 2 995 000 π cm³  
 instead of  3 000 000 π cm³.

Hence

 Cost = (2 995 000 π) / 5 000 ≃ 1 882.4 $,

whereas you obtained 1 884.96 $.  
The difference (~ 2.8 $) comes entirely from the slight over-estimate of the fence volume.

SUMMARY OF THE ERROR  
Step 3: treating the curved 10 cm-thick fence as length × height × thickness at the outer radius.  
Correct treatment: subtract the two semicircular areas (or sum thin rings) before multiplying by the height.

Everything else in your solution (radius = 3 m, full circular floor, halving the fence, price conversion) is consistent with the intended answer.

Question:
Question: The game of penultimate frisbee has two scoring moves: the bungee and the wedgie.
Each type of score is worth an odd prime number of points, with a bungee being worth more than a wedgie.  If the largest score that can never be achieved in a game is 95 points (no matter how long the game lasts), how many points is each move worth?
 Your Solution: The bungee is worth 17 points, and the wedgie is worth 7.
The largest score that can not be achieved by some combination of p and q points, with p relatively prime to q, is p*q-p-q = (p-1)*(q-1)-1.
So 96 must be factorable as (p-1)*(q-1), for odd primes p and q.
Since the prime factorization of 96 = 2^5*3, and each of the two
factors must be even, the possible factorizations are:
2*48
4*24
8*12
16*6
Only the last factorization yields two factors each of which is one less
than an odd prime, so 17 and 7 must be the two primes we seek.
 Correct Solution: Let W be the point value of a wedgie and B the point value of a bungee.

1. Both scores are odd primes and B > W.
2. Any game score is a non‑negative integer combination of W and B.
3. For two relatively prime positive integers, the largest unattainable score is  
   G = WB − W − B (the Frobenius “coin problem” formula).  
   Here G = 95.

   WB − W − B = 95  
   ⇒ WB − W − B + 1 = 96  
   ⇒ (W − 1)(B − 1) = 96.

4. Set a = W − 1 and b = B − 1.  
   Then a·b = 96 with a < b, and both W = a + 1 and B = b + 1 must be odd primes.

   Factor pairs of 96:
   1·96 (2, 97) 2 is not odd  
   2·48 (3, 49) 49 not prime  
   3·32 (4, 33) 4 not prime  
   4·24 (5, 25) 25 not prime  
   6·16 (7, 17) both 7 and 17 are odd primes  ✔  
   8·12 (9, 13) 9 not prime

   The only valid pair is a = 6, b = 16.

5. Therefore  
   W = a + 1 = 7 points,  
   B = b + 1 = 17 points.

Final answer: The wedgie is worth 7 points and the bungee is worth 17 points.
Hint:
If the two moves are worth p and q, the largest score that can not be
achieved by some combination  of bungees and wedgies is p*q-p-q.
Human Solution:
The bungee is worth 17 points, and the wedgie is worth 7.
The largest score that can not be achieved by some combination of p and q points, with p relatively prime to q, is p*q-p-q = (p-1)*(q-1)-1.
So 96 must be factorable as (p-1)*(q-1), for odd primes p and q.
Since the prime factorization of 96 = 2^5*3, and each of the two
factors must be even, the possible factorizations are:
2*48
4*24
8*12
16*6
Only the last factorization yields two factors each of which is one less
than an odd prime, so 17 and 7 must be the two primes we seek.
Response:
After comparing the two write-ups it is clear that your argument leads to the same numerical answer as the official solution (17 and 7).  The mathematical steps you used are essentially the same and are valid, so there is no substantive logical error that would give the wrong result.  The only very small issues are matters of completeness or exposition rather than correctness:

1. Justifying the use of the Frobenius formula  
   You stated the formula G = pq − p − q without explicitly pointing out that it requires gcd(p,q)=1.  Because p and q are given to be (odd) primes this is automatically satisfied, but mentioning it would make the application of the formula airtight.

2. Factor-pair list of 96  
   • You restricted attention to even factors (correct, because p−1 and q−1 are even) but you presented only four ordered pairs: 2·48, 4·24, 8·12, 16·6.  
   • You implicitly discarded the odd–even pairs 1·96 and 3·32 (correctly) and you did not list the “reflections’’ 6·16, 12·8, 24·4, 48·2, which are merely the same four pairs with the factors reversed.  Nothing is wrong here—omitting duplicates does not affect the conclusion—but the official solution showed all even*even pairs explicitly for completeness.

3. Verification that 95 is indeed the largest unattainable score  
   The Frobenius formula guarantees this, but you did not comment that once (p−1)(q−1)=96 all scores above 95 are attainable.  Again, this is not an error—just a step you could have mentioned for completeness.

4. Terminology  
   You wrote “only the last factorization yields two factors each of which is one less than an odd prime, so 17 and 7 must be the two primes we seek.”  It would have been slightly clearer to add “and since the bungee is the higher score, it must be 17.”

In short, your solution is mathematically correct; the differences from the official write-up are superficial and do not affect the validity of the answer.

than an odd prime, so 17 and 7 must be the two primes we seek.

Human Solution:

Response:
After comparing every step, your derivation gives the same pair of primes (7 , 17) as the official solution, and it does so for exactly the same reason:

• You used the Frobenius-coin bound G = WB − W − B.  
• You rewrote G = 95 as (W − 1)(B − 1) = 96.  
• You enumerated the factor pairs of 96 and kept only those that make W and B odd primes with B > W.  
• That leaves the single possibility 7 and 17.

All numerical work and all logical justifications are correct, and you did not miss any potential factor pairs.  The only very minor omissions one might mention are:

1. Coprimality was not stated explicitly (though it is automatic because distinct odd primes are always coprime).  
2. You did not mention that the factor pair (16, 6) is the same as (6, 16) once the “larger prime is the bungee” condition is applied, but that does not affect the conclusion.

These are stylistic rather than substantive; they do not change the answer or the validity of the reasoning.  Hence there are no actual mathematical errors in your solution—the wedgie is 7 points and the bungee is 17 points, exactly as in the official solution.
